Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Scar Quality After Hydrosurgical Versus Conventional Debridement in Burn Patients

Trial_Design.evidence: A multicentre, double-blind, randomised controlled trial

Participants.evidence: Eligible participants had burns requiring split-skin grafting.

Intervention.evidence: Each patient had two wound areas, one randomised to hydrosurgical debridement and the other to Weck knife debridement.

Objective.evidence: This trial aimed to evaluate scar quality following hydrosurgical versus conventional debridement before split-skin grafting in burn patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was scar quality at 12 months, assessed using the observer part of the Patient and Observer Scar Assessment Scale (POSAS).

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a web-based system, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Both patients and outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 137 patients were randomised between January 2017 and July 2019.

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 12 months, the hydrosurgically debrided wounds had a lower POSAS observer total item score (mean difference -0.12, 95% CI -0.22 to -0.02; p = 0.023) and overall opinion score (mean difference -0.22, 95% CI -0.34 to -0.09; p = 0.006).

Harms.evidence: No significant differences in complication rates, including wound infection and graft loss, were observed between the groups.

Funding.evidence: This study was funded by the Dutch Burns Foundation (grant number 15.101).
